trans-unit.source: Up to this point, we have been primarily challenging students to collaborate while they create their own projects.
trans-unit.target: Up to this point, we have been primarily challenging students to collaborate while they create their own projects.

trans-unit.source: This lesson, on communication using the micro:bit radio, is a great opportunity to have students work in pairs on a project.
trans-unit.target: This lesson, on communication using the micro:bit radio, is a great opportunity to have students work in pairs on a project.

trans-unit.source: Have kids find a partner to work with for this lesson, and make sure they are seated next to each other.
trans-unit.target: Have kids find a partner to work with for this lesson, and make sure they are seated next to each other.

trans-unit.source: Note: Many teachers find the concept of “pair programming” to be a valuable way to have students collaborate when programming.
trans-unit.target: Note: Many teachers find the concept of “pair programming” to be a valuable way to have students collaborate when programming.

trans-unit.source: Two students share one computer, with one student at the keyboard acting as the driver, and the other student providing directions as the navigator.
trans-unit.target: Two students share one computer, with one student at the keyboard acting as the driver, and the other student providing directions as the navigator.

trans-unit.source: Students must practice good communication with each other throughout the entire programming process.
trans-unit.target: Students must practice good communication with each other throughout the entire programming process.

trans-unit.source: The micro:bit allows you to communicate with other micro:bits in the area using the blocks in the Radio category.
trans-unit.target: The micro:bit allows you to communicate with other micro:bits in the area using the blocks in the Radio category.

trans-unit.source: You can send a number, a string (a word or series of characters) or a string/number combination in a radio packet.
trans-unit.target: You can send a number, a string (a word or series of characters) or a string/number combination in a radio packet.

trans-unit.source: You can also give a micro:bit instructions on what to do when it receives a radio packet.
trans-unit.target: You can also give a micro:bit instructions on what to do when it receives a radio packet.

trans-unit.source: This lesson starts with a “plugged” unplugged activity, in which students use their micro:bits to explore an advanced simulation.
trans-unit.target: This lesson starts with a “plugged” unplugged activity, in which students use their micro:bits to explore an advanced simulation.

trans-unit.source: The code is quite complex, so students will focus more on how to use the micro:bits to explore aspects of viruses and epidemics, than the intricacies of the code itself.
trans-unit.target: The code is quite complex, so students will focus more on how to use the micro:bits to explore aspects of viruses and epidemics, than the intricacies of the code itself.

trans-unit.source: The project for this lesson will challenge students to work together to send and receive some sort of data to and from each other.
trans-unit.target: The project for this lesson will challenge students to work together to send and receive some sort of data to and from each other.

trans-unit.source: There is a wide range of simple and complex projects kids can try, but whatever they choose it is a whole lot of fun to communicate with each other using the micro:bits!
trans-unit.target: There is a wide range of simple and complex projects kids can try, but whatever they choose it is a whole lot of fun to communicate with each other using the micro:bits!
